Fields.DialogueText: Marat, I can't get traction on this floor! Why is it so slick?
Kapitan, you noticed! I have been working hard at cleaning the floors.
I can't argue that. But tell me - why did you clean the floors instead of the crew? I know it's not one of your ordinary duties.
They told me that cleaning the floors was a dull task, Kapitan. Don't worry, though - I have assigned them the delightfully exhilarating job of cleaning the heads.
Heh. But you're supposed to be off-duty - why all this work?
With a clean ship we will defeat the Neizvestniy Flot. With hard work we will have bread, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: Next time put up a warning sign about the floors.
That's kind of a non-sequitur, isn't it? But, okay, bread.
Have the crew assigned to another task.

Fields.DialogueText: Est! The sign shall read "Watch your step, floors are underfoot."
Bread will provide your body with sustained energy for battles, Kapitan.
Est! I will assign the crew to clean the galley.
Those thoughts were very... cleansing. Now I just need to slide my way back down...
Maybe you need a new pair of shoes. Those don't look like they have sufficient traction for this flooring.

Fields.MenuText: I think I'm going to slide out of here.
These shoes will be better once the floor is dried.
Don't forget a warning sign.

Fields.DialogueText: See? You're adapting already!
Da, Kapitan. There is no rushing a job well done.
Da, Kapitan. I strive always to be inclusive.
*ALARM*
Well, that's admirable. Borderline dangerous, but admirable.
A clean floor is a ready floor.
Whoop!
I commend your diligence, but there's about to be a lot of running around.
Very well. I'll set to roping this space off...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Privet, Kapitan. I'm sorry you couldn't sleep until your shift.
Sleep isn't really on my mind right now, Marat.
How long until they're in range?
Not so long at all.
@BATTLE
Holy... Marat, are you all right?!
Nyet. I was assisting in the sick bay. If I were British, you would say that I was having a "bloody good time."
Some of our crew members have wounds which needed immediate medical attention. One had shrapnel lodged in his great saphenous...
That's... okay. I'm just glad you were there to help.
The human body is so fascinating, Kapitan. Down in the sickbay I feel like Mikhail Bulgakov learning how the human body works.

Fields.MenuText: Who is Mikhail Bulgakov?
... Okay, I'll bite. What is a great saphenous?
How did you learn to mend injured crew members?

Fields.DialogueText: A doctor who then became a writer - and a playwright. You may have seen some of his work if you've ever been to Moscow. "Dni Turbinykh?"
The great saphenous is a major vein of the thigh, Kapitan.
Someone left French-language medical journals onboard at one point. They're very interesting reading.
That's certainly fascinating.
Oh. Sorry, Kapitan - looks like your shoes got stained a little.
Oh? Ah, they seem fine to me, Marat.
I'd be happy to take them! I find that cleaning for long periods of time is a lot like meditation.

Fields.MenuText: But what would I wear in the meantime?
Why do you want my shoes?
How is cleaning a form of meditation?

Fields.DialogueText: Another pair of shoes and a nice pair of wool socks, Kapitan.
Well, it's not so much the shoe as what is on the shoe. I need at least one shoe to repair my belt, Kapitan.
Cleaning is a menial task that leaves my mind free to wander and reflect, Kapitan.
Da, Kapitan. Why do you ask?
You're covered in blood.
Ah. So I am. Mne zhal'.
It isn't yours, I take it.
This... actually may not be the right time for this conversation, Marat.
I take your point.
You can't just cannibalize my clothing.
Do not worry. It will be returned to you good as new!
And if those go missing?
Why, I'd recommend against that.
As opposed to surgery.
Well, of course! Imagine the carnage otherwise. Better yet, do not.
What do you see, Marat?
Something is out in the distance, right on the horizon. See that reflecting over there? I don't know what it is, but...
I don't see it.
Try looking with your eyes. If it were a bear, it would have ambushed you. The light is reflecting off of something metallic.
*ALARM*
That solves the mystery. Sadly, it is not a bear at sea.
It seems that my curiosity always gets the better of me.
@BATTLE
With guns we will defeat the enemy, with determination we claim victory, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: It was too easy, if you ask me.
Let's make sure the fires are out before we congratulate ourselves. That was... painful.
That was just... extremely satisfying.

Fields.DialogueText: Too easy? I am very sorry to hear that, Kapitan. Maybe we should play a game of chess if you are looking for a challenge?
Oh, I am very sorry to hear you say that, Kapitan. Perhaps we should sharpen our tactics with a game of chess?
Congratulations, Kapitan! I knew we could do it with perseverance. They key is to never give up. Why don't we unwind with a game of chess?
I might be game... for a game of chess.
Here are the terms, Kapitan: if I win, I get to see your shoes. If you win, I have to clean your shoes.
Wait, what type of terms are those?
Favorable ones for us both. I might win more than you do, but we will both win in the end.
Marat, why is everything strewn around? It looks like a shell detonated in here...
I am sorry, Kapitan. I cannot find my box. It was in my gear a moment ago, but now it's gone.
What box?
It is a box of chocolate - or chocolat, as the Parisians call it. It looks like a small ammo crate.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe it's just hard to find it in all of this fog.
It's just chocolate. We can buy more later.
Maybe it was lost in the last battle with the Morganas. In fact - what if they took the chocolate?

Fields.DialogueText: Probably.
You are right, Kapitan. It is an embarrassment of riches when others are waiting for a mere slice of bread.
It will come around again. Until then, they will break under our perseverance.
We'll look again when the fog clears. I bet they'll turn up.
Kapitan, you took your shoes off to relax, da?
Where the hell are my shoes?
Kapitan, I've just noticed the Neizvestniy Flot in the distance have taken to our heels... in both the figurative and literal way.
This fog won't be of any help to us in the coming battle.
Fog is just the added challenge I was seeking, sir! I like to think one move ahead, right to that point where I crush their ego.
@BATTLE
Hmm. I know I'm worrying more than I should, but good chocolate is so hard to come by - and French chocolate on the sea is even more scarce.
... And yet you're still looking around my quarters.
Yes. And...?
Where did you put them?
Over th...
Mne nuzhen pereryv. I think I will go unwind by taking inventory of the remaining ammunition.
Perhaps you can take inventory of where my shoes went. Even after that last battle, they have yet to make a reappearance.
Kapitan, I come to the conclusion that your shoes were not lucky. Without them, you were victorious in battle. I foresee future victories in their absence.

Fields.MenuText: My feet are cold, damn it. The sea air cuts right through my socks.
Right. Of course. How important are shoes on a ship, anyway?
Where are my shoes?

Fields.DialogueText: Have you tried wool socks, Kapitan?
That can only be answered based on the experiences of the person asking. If you can persevere through this, you will find the answer to your question.
Your shoes must be somewhere, Kapitan. I will look for them right away.
These are encouraging words in tough times. Now watch: my shoes will magically reappear when I least expect them to.
The missing shoes will be found. It's as good as done... right after we are victorious over the Neizvestniy Flot that are headed our way.
Wonderful. For the record, battle while barefoot isn't incredibly appealing.
Do not get emotionally tied up with your shoes right now. Emotions and fears have no place in battle.
You are not going to make me feel bad about wanting my shoes back. You're just not.
@BATTLE
Sounds pleasant, no?
Kapitan! Kapitan, I have such wonderful news! Your shoes have been recovered.
Where have they been all this time?
In a turret barrel. I found them while I was inspecting the guns.
Okay. So they must have been put there after the last battle. And after the last round of maintenance. That's... weird.
Look after your clothes when they're spick and span, and look after your honor when you're a kapitan.
One - that doesn't even begin to address the issue at hand. Two - did you just make that poem up?
Oh, it's a common rhyme, but I added "kapitan" to make it more topical. Come to think of it, all this action has me as hungry as a hunter.

Fields.MenuText: I'm feeling hungry myself.
So we're really just not going to address my shoes at all?
And what's for dessert?

Fields.DialogueText: Let's make a big meal for the crew to enjoy. They have worked tirelessly and a grand dinner will help keep crew morale high. A happy crew is an efficient crew.
Just be glad they're back, Kapitan. Now, what are your thoughts on pickled sprats?
Your directness is admirable, Kapitan! Dessert is the chocolate icing on the cake.
*ALARM*
There must be a clever witticism about not going into battle on an empty stomach...
Hmm... you get to really know your friends when trouble comes.
That doesn't actually have anything to do with food, Marat.
Victory will make the meal taste even sweeter?
@BATTLE
Okay. That one works.
Finally! Let's eat.
Our crew will enjoy the delightful dinner of head cheese borscht, hardtack for the stew, bread, pickled cabbage, and some fruit leathers for dessert.
Anything more... palatable?
We cannot be picky in times of war, Kapitan. This buffet has adequate nutrition to fuel our endeavors and will keep crew morale high. An efficient crew is an efficient ship.
... Okay, I won't say I haven't had worse.
Oh! I nearly forgot! We need to get the vodka.
Do we have vodka? I know we have rations of beer.
The crew cannot toast with simple beer, Kapitan. Firstly, it will not bode well for morale. Secondly, it is bad superstition to toast with beer. We need vodka. V etot moment.

Fields.MenuText: I'm beginning to understand how someone could forget putting my shoes down the barrel of a gun.
I'll stick to the ration of beer, thanks.
Have you considered being a teetotaler ship?

Fields.DialogueText: It's not good to dwell on such things. Dwell on vodka.
Da... Kapitan. If you are prepared for the consequences.
Have you a smooth relationship with the crew? The answers to those questions are opposites.
*ALARM*
Our toast will just have to wait.
@BATTLE
Marat, why is there a chair in the middle of the corridor? I nearly tripped and broke my neck.
I'm trying to get enough seating for the dinner, Kapitan.
There's always the floor.
That wouldn't be fair to the crew. Everyone has worked hard to this point. This dinner is to keep morale up, and we need seating.

Fields.MenuText: Find some trunks and use those as benches.
We're not going to get the entire crew in here at one time anyway. We just do it in shifts over several hours.
Crates would work.

Fields.DialogueText: What an excellent idea, Kapitan! Everyone will have a seat, then.
Then some will feel favored over others! Nyet!
Crates are a very calculated idea, Kapitan! I'll go drag those into position.
Hm. I'm getting more famished by the minute.
Only... a few... more... seats... left! Ah...
Morganas are coming into range, Kapitan!
I hope you saved enough energy, Marat.
Chert poberi! The wicked shall know no peace.
@BATTLE
I'm happy to entertain alternatives.
Khorosho. I'll think of something.
All right, Marat - you had me fooled. I thought dinner was going to make me lose my appetite but it tasted better than I could have imagined.
Dinner is what our crew needed to keep morale up. Now we just need to find some vodka and toast to the crew before it's too late.
Never mind! it looks like the Neizvestniy Flot have heard our intentions to toast.
@BATTLE
Okay. If you want to look for vodka now, I think the crew's earned it. In moderation, yes, but...
One moment, Kapitan. There's a fishing vessel nearby - see it? If the enemy was harassing it before we arrived, they may need assistance.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, let's help them. As you've been known to say, "You really get to know your friends when trouble comes."
Hail them first. If they're able to sail, they might not want to waste time with us before getting back home.
Approach cautiously. If the Morganas left behind a booby trap, I don't want to blunder into it.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, I am overjoyed to see you heeded my advice! The next toast will be to friends.
Da, Kapitan. It's a good thought.
Da, Kapitan. It's a good thought.
Let's get started, then. If they really are in trouble we shouldn't dally.
*ALARM*
Been a while since I've seen seas this rough. And you're the first crew member I've seen in half an hour who isn't at least faintly green.
It seems to be a beam sea, Kapitan. We will have to change the angle of the ship, or we might get caught in a wave and risk rolling over.
It wasn't supposed to be this bad. I tend to think stories about Morganas manipulating the weather are bunk, but...
Nevazhno! We have come this far and we can't give up now. This sea will be conquered one way or another.
Prepare to feel the ship pitch, Kapitan. Brace yourself for the impact of the wave.
*CREAK*
We are pitching again - hold onto something bolted down!
*CREAK*

Fields.MenuText: How's the ship holding up?
Really gets the blood pumping, doesn't it?
I think I'm going to be sick...

Fields.DialogueText: Ya khorosho sebya chuvstvuyu! No problems to report, Kapitan!
That's the spirit, Kapitan!
A nice opportunity to benchmark how fast your stomach can pass food. How long ago was your last meal?
I'm really going to feel this tomorrow. Say, is that fog rolling in?
I have a feeling it is the Neizvestniy Flot...
Okay, so - we're going to have a battle when we can barely hold onto the ship. This should be fun.
If we can make it through this rough sea and battle, everything will seem easier on the other side.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Hold steady, Marat.
When do I not?
Heh. Fair point.
@BATTLE
Another trawler? The storm knocked these poor people a long way from the coast...
Da. But at least rescuing them is smooth sailing compared to what we've just gone through.
Har, har.
Approaching the vessel.
Oh, I hope it was worth the trouble of fighting through that lot to rescue this ship...
Pff. You'd've been the first one to raise hell if we hadn't done it. Heck, I could probably just kick back and leave you in charge for this kind of thing.
Ha, ha! With my background?! Oh goodness, no. I would rather follow than lead. The responsibility is on the kapitan, not the First Comrade.
Your background?
Some of the surviving crew members are coming to board - let's talk to the officers.

Fields.MenuText: What about the question?
How many surviving crew members are there?
Can we salvage anything off that vessel before it goes down?

Fields.DialogueText: I am going to see if any of our officers need help!
It is hard to tell how many there are. I'm going to see if any of our officers need help.
It looks like there are many assets on that ship. I will coordinate with the officers, Kapitan.
... I don't think that boat's going to stay afloat too long. We need to prepare for some civilian guests.
Da.
What are all these ammunition crates doing here? Are you sure that was a fishing vessel, Marat?
It was repurposed as cargo ships became scarce, Kapitan. Now the entire crew can toast to an unexpected windfall!
So. Where are we going to put the extra people?

Fields.MenuText: Extra people on board means extra mouths to feed.
Congratulations, you have more people to enlist in your chore campaign.
Maybe we can construct a giant chessboard on deck and use the fishermen as chess pieces.

Fields.DialogueText: We can use the catch that was on the fishing boat to help feed everyone. Problem solved.
With pristine guns we will defeat the Neizvestniy Flot, with hard work we will have bread, Kapitan!
That sounds like a delightful idea to play out one day. Let's recreate the 1910 Roesch vs Schlage match that took place in Hamburg.
I wonder if any of them play chess...
Would any of them honestly be a challenge to you?
That's why I will play them all simultaneously!
I will weep for the crew.
*ALARM*
Remember, battle is like chess.  Think one move ahead, to that point where you crush their ego.
@BATTLE
Given that it's not actually ammunition we can use, I'd say the crew might want to save the toast.
Don't be such a grump. We'll be able to unload it all at port - and perhaps negotiate a trade or two at the same time.
I like your spirit, anyway.
Spasibo!
Time... to celebrate! The crew has their glasses and crates.
Watch it there! Your elbow nearly broke my nose. Could you pass me a glass while you're at it?
Da. Of course!
This isn't a glass, it's a sediment bowl...
It's a glass sediment bowl! They were washed earlier. They make fine toasting glasses, don't they?

Fields.MenuText: Are we really toasting out of these?
You're a better chess player than a hostess.

Fields.DialogueText: These sediment bowls have worked hard, just like our crew, Kapitan.
Thank you for noticing my dedication to the game of chess, Kapitan!
Is everyone ready? Hold your glass up high. To victory and friendship!
To victory and friendship!

Fields.MenuText: I can't deny you're creative.

Fields.DialogueText: Victory goes to she who discovers new ways of securing it!
Is everything in place for the dinner?
So many witches about, and you do not ask about the battle? For shame!
I know you're ready. Just thinking one move ahead, like you say.
As am I! That is the advantage of using crates and other everyday objects for our fancy furniture. There is always extra seating!
@BATTLE
Kapitan, I need you over here in sick bay to look at something.
What is it, Marat - another torn leg?
Oh, no... it's not that.
Okay, Marat, for a minute there I thought you were going to show me somethi-
Excellent, Kapitan! I applaud your command of human anatomy!
No need to be scared, Kapitan. We all have one... well, most of us do.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't realize you fancied the macabre.
Do the Morganas have hearts?
That is... that was part of a member of your crew, Marat. You will not use it as a toy or a prop. Do you understand me?

Fields.DialogueText: I fancy medical science and anatomy. It's so interesting to see how things and people work.
Learning about the Neizvestniy Flot up close would be an education I would not want to miss!
Kapitan, I wouldn't! The doctor is giving me a chance to further my medical education, so I can be of more help!
*ALARM*
This might be our chance to learn how the Neizvestniy Flot are put together.
@BATTLE
Glad to hear it. Pardon me, Midshipman - just passing through.
Marat. Am I correct in observing that you're holding a human heart in your hand?
I'm sure you'll find the opportunity. Just... put that heart down.
A place for everything, da?
Kapitan, you have such a sorrowful look on your face...
Marat, my shoes are missing. Again.
Here today, gone tomorrow. You never know what the next chapter will be, Kapitan.
Be it the future or the present, footwear is still required.
To bake a cake, one must crack a few eggs.

Fields.MenuText: I don't see how that relates.
What you're saying is that I have to lose my shoes before I can find them again?
Can you just get me some shoes already?

Fields.DialogueText: It relates in how you must lose your shoes before you can find them again, Kapitan.
Est! Some things are state-dependent like that.
Da, Kapitan!
Right. This is a ship. There's only so many places they could actually be.
How long did it take to find them last time they were missing?
Far longer than had I anticipated.
Ready to recreate our previous experiment?
Morganas are closing in, aren't they?
Da, Kapitan. And we will deal with them as before.
@BATTLE
Hello? Marat, are you down in the sick bay again? Marat! Are you down there?
Da, Kapitan! I think I found you a pair of shoes.
Wonderful! Coming down to get them now.
Here you go, Kapitan.
These aren't my shoes...
These are a fine pair of sapogi.
Where did these come from, Marat?
From an individual who left us here in the sick bay, Kapitan.
If we're talking about a deceased crew member, this shouldn't be anonymous, Marat.
Petty Officer Andrienko, Kapitan. But the shoes are just shoes, and I don't think they should go to waste if they can be useful.

Fields.MenuText: No, thank you.
... Okay. Maybe it's not the worst thing in the world to have a reminder of the price we're paying out here.
Clean the mess up, at least.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. I will have the crew bring to you a new pair, then.
I agree, Kapitan.
I thought you would never ask, Kapitan. It's as good as done.
*ALARM*
Duty calls! You'd better get your shoes on for the battle.
This feels so wrong...
@BATTLE
Marat, this place is a mess - and here I thought you worshipped good, back-breaking cleaning work.
In order to bake a cake, one must crack a few eggs, Kapitan.
The crew and myself are turning this ship on its head to look for those shoes.

Fields.MenuText: You told the crew about my shoes?
How long before this is all cleaned up?
Have you checked in the gun barrels?

Fields.DialogueText: A good kapitan should have nothing to hide. Nothing to hide is nothing to fear, Kapitan.
I have a small crew to help with chores, but I've tended to get confused about time ever since my country converted to the Gregorian calendar.
More than once, Kapitan.
Okay. Enough disruption for now. Let's just get all this cleaned up.
It's as good as done, Kapitan.
*ALARM*
I've been craving a good exercise in strategy and tactics, Kapitan.
Haven't you been playing chess with the crew?
Now they beg me not to play chess. They said given a choice, they would rather clean than play against me.
@BATTLE
I thought your bulkheads looked pristine lately.
Shiny enough for me to see myself without an opponent. C'est la vie.
Marat, I'm... astonished. The place looks even more organized than when we started. Last time I looked, it was a pigsty.
Seeing you notice my efforts brings a smile to my face. We are currently about 60% reorganized, Kapitan.
How do you find the time to do all of this?
You'd be surprised how much one can accomplish if one doesn't sleep.
How is that possible?
I like to think of myself as an albatross. They fly at sea for months on end.

Fields.MenuText: Surely they sleep, though. Right?
That's downright poetic, Marat.
That sounds absolutely exhausting.

Fields.DialogueText: That is a good question, Kapitan! Care to make it interesting?
Perhaps not from the albatross's point of view. But it is content with its lot.
And yet they've adapted to it.
Of course, the albatross has to be wary of aquatic predators when she does rest. And, on that note...
@BATTLE
Why are you slumped over, Marat? Is everything okay?
Oh, my apologies, Kapitan. I was just resting for a minute.
I felt a little tired... no peace for the wicked, is there?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you should sleep.
Have you tried counting sheep?
Do you even have a bed?

Fields.DialogueText: If I sleep... Hah. I might miss the action, Kapitan.
Do barnacles count as sheep?
You know, Kapitan, I don't think I've even looked for my bed yet.
What's the real reason behind you not sleeping?
I prefer to keep my mind occupied. It helps me ignore certain... emotions.
Experiencing emotions, in and of itself, isn't problematic. In fact, I'd say suppressing emotions generally indicates some deeper issue.
Eto mozhet byt' pravdoy... but experiencing emotions like compassion during times of war can lead to other, less pleasant emotions.
... I suppose that's the reason why I don't have many friends.
Menial labor is what I do in a stressful situation. It allows me to reflect and be productive at the same time.
*ALARM*
Ah, perfect! Eto kak raz to, chto mne nuzhno! This will clear my mind.
@BATTLE
Like sorrow.
*KNOCK*
Come in!
Marat? What's on your mind?
Kapitan, I've been thinking...

Fields.MenuText: I thought I heard a grinding noise.
About?
That makes one of us.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha, ha! I enjoy your sense of humor, Kapitan. I've been thinking... are Neizvestniy Flot like people?
I've been thinking... are Neizvestniy Flot like people?
Ha, ha! I enjoy your sense of humor, Kapitan. I've been thinking... are Neizvestniy Flot like people?
What do you mean? In what way?
The Neizvestniy Flot are the enemy and they are organized, but do they crave each other's companionship? Do they have human emotions? Do you think they dream?

Fields.MenuText: If we work from the assumption that they're metaphysically similar to Belles, it's possible.
Shoot first and ask questions later, that's what I always say.
Is the ship reorganization finished yet?

Fields.DialogueText: The better we can understand the Neizvestniy Flot, the more we can keep one move ahead of them, Kapitan.
If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles. This can bode well for shooting.
Getting back on that, Kapitan!
For what it's worth, I've probably had more contact with the enemy than most - and my gut feeling is that they crave companionship, they have emotions, and maybe they even dream.
And the thrills never stop. The Neizvestniy Flot are inbound and nearly in range.
@BATTLE
Any particular reason it's on your mind?
And I think they're just too broken and too suspicious and too violent to make any of it work for them.
Which makes our job just a thrill a minute.
Is Marat down in sick bay aga... Woah!
Ouch! What's that on the floor?
Are you okay, Kapitan? I heard a crash.
Am I dreaming? Marat, pinch me.
Kapitan, I don't understand...
Look what I just tripped over.
Kapitan, are those your shoes?
I'd nearly forgotten about them.
You've been sitting on them this entire time?

Fields.MenuText: Did you put the shoes here?
What do I do with this other pair?
I'm not even going to ask questions at this point.

Fields.DialogueText: Why would I put something out of its place, Kapitan?
They might be good luck, Kapitan, as we've come this far with you wearing them!
Now you can step off on the right foot, Kapitan.
Captain, Morganas are inbound.
No time to kick off your shoes, Kapitan...
@BATTLE
Ha ha. I'm keeping these close for the rest of the tour.
I'll never take this pair of shoes for granted. I'd forgotten what a fitted pair felt like.
Do they fit as good as chocolate tastes?
Oh, yes, your chocolate...
Ladno. I'm sure a new lace can be acquired, Kapitan.
Now, let's think for a minute. Who besides myself has been the only other individual in this room?
Ma... My... rat?

Fields.MenuText: You have a rat?
Nice try.
Oh, how the sea can change...

Fields.DialogueText: Ships can have rats, Kapitan. I might have a few in my engine room.
Kapitan, it was... I only meant to...
Who are you quoting, Kapitan?
A good effort, but you can't talk your way out of this one.
*ALARM*
We can fight our way out of this one!
@BATTLE
Hang on. Where's this one's shoelace?
That's a strange box. What are you're carrying? Ammunition for your rifle?
One of the crew members had a box of Parisian chocolat that looked just like the one I lost.
They wanted to thank the First Comrade for keeping morale up.

Fields.MenuText: That smells a tad fishy...
What was this person's name?
Are they connected with the shoe snatcher?

Fields.DialogueText: Being at sea for prolonged periods of time can make anything smell fishy, Kapitan. Even this chocolat.
Their name doesn't matter, Kapitan. Only their generosity.
That would tie everything together, Kapitan!
Let me enjoy a moment in the welcoming bliss that is this chocolat. Oops!
Did a shoe lace just fall out of that tin, Marat?
O-oh, that's where it went off to.
You collected my laces? I thought you were against getting attached to things?
With that being said, Kapitan, I am not against collecting memorabilia. Of course, it's all incidental and not integral... if you understand.
Well, you do have your eccentric belt that's constructed out of a chain, and a chess piece necklace. If the shoe fits...
You noticed them, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: They're very obvious. Who wears a chain as a fashion statement?
What books won't you read?
I'm done with small talk. Get back to work.

Fields.DialogueText: We should all have the luxury of making such a statement. Perhaps when the proletarians have thrown off their chains...
What's the difference between a dog and a book?
Est! It's as good as done.
*ALARM*
À bientôt, mon chocolat.
@BATTLE
I don't know, what is the difference between a dog and a book?
Outside of a dog, a book is man's best friend. Inside of a dog, it's too dark to read.
I've always been curious about your accoutrements, Marat. Now that we have a moment to catch our breath, what is the story behind them?
Do you mean the chess piece around my neck?
Yeah - is it for luck?
Nyet. This pawn serves as a reminder.
Reminder of what?
It symbolizes that we each have a vital contribution to make to the game, no matter how powerful or powerless we may seem.
If that's what a little chess piece means to you, then what does the chain represent?
The chain on my belt is a different story, Kapitan. It reminds me of a broken past with many different links. Each link is akin to a chapter in a story.
Why is there a broken link?
A chain is only as strong as the weakest link, Kapitan. You have shown dedication. With your shoelace I can mend my broken chain and start a new chapter.
Another notch on your belt. But let me ask you this...

Fields.MenuText: What if the shoelace breaks?
What if the shoelace comes untied?
What's the probability of this also disappearing?

Fields.DialogueText: Shoelaces can fray with time. You still have the other shoelace...
Why, we must use superior nautical knots, Kapitan. A knot is strong enough to keep a ship tied to a dock.
Nothing is certain in life, Kapitan. This is what keeps life exciting.
*ALARM*
Remember, Kapitan, battle is like chess. Think one move ahead, right to that point where you crush their ego.
@BATTLE
That was a long haul.
It was a good test of strategy and determination, Kapitan!
I'm still not sold on the entire shoelace metaphor. Shoelaces can break.
Even intangible things such as friendship can break. Romances can break, hearts can break...

Fields.MenuText: Still too soon for heart imagery, Marat.

Fields.DialogueText: Da. Each link is like a chapter. Friendships can break. However, they can also grow, link by link.
It was the strongest of chains, it was the weakest of chains.
I like how your sense of humor has grown! You are indeed a Renaissance kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: You say that now. Wait until I start hitting you with the albatross jokes I've been saving up.
I do aim to please.

Fields.DialogueText: Getting back to the chain. You said that each link was a chapter in a book...
Prostite, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: Not ours, Marat. We're in this for the long haul.
What's broken can be fixed, of course.

Fields.DialogueText: I would follow you to the end of the very longest!
That is how you build a new world, is it not? All the pieces are in place... just waiting to be put to a better use.
Hit me with as many as you like! I'll strike back on the chessboard.
And quite the marksman you are.
Takes one to know one. Let's put that to use.
I'm expecting it when we're done here.
